content: The scheme of things is so huge it cannot be comprehended in human time or space. We live on a little garden of Eden planet somewhere out here...in the universe. Do we really know where in the whole universe where we really are located? Probably not, which is even more interesting!

title: Just how big is the universe?

content: What's amazing is that it's getting bigger. That is the true obstacle to interstellar travel. Forget problems of navigation or speed....the distance between two points is changing at an astonishing rate, so if we don't go to the stars ASAP, we may never be able to. Re: the poster who wrote about Einstein's theories being proven wrong, well...nothing would please scientists more. Physicists are people who get excited when their theories are proven incorrect, because it brings them that much closer to the real answer. It's when the evidence of an experiment supports their theories that the theorists feel a bit let down. Science is about the search for knowledge, not the accumulation of it.
reply: What's amazing is that it's getting bigger. That is the true obstacle to interstellar travel. Forget problems of navigation or speed....the distance between two points is changing at an astonishing rate, so if we don't go to the stars ASAP, we may never be able to. Physicists are people who get excited when their theories are proven incorrect, because it brings them that much closer to the real answer. It's when the evidence of an experiment supports their theories that the theorists feel a bit let down. Science is about the search for knowledge, not the accumulation of it.
title: Just how big is the universe?

content: Einstein's theories will very likely be found to be incomplete and require a tad of "tweaking" here and there, but in the main, they've been borne out by observation and repetition! The catch is in reconciling his thoughts with the discipline of Quantum Physics (or vice-versa)! It is not our belief or disbelief that can make or unmake the fact. ~ Thomas Paine

reply: The scheme of things is so huge it cannot be comprehended in human time or space. We live on a little garden of Eden planet somewhere out here...in the universe. Do we really know where in the whole universe where we really are located? Probably not, which is even more interesting!
title: Just how big is the universe?

content: What's amazing is that it's getting bigger. That is the true obstacle to interstellar travel. Forget problems of navigation or speed....the distance between two points is changing at an astonishing rate, so if we don't go to the stars ASAP, we may never be able to. Re: the poster who wrote about Einstein's theories being proven wrong, well...nothing would please scientists more. Physicists are people who get excited when their theories are proven incorrect, because it brings them that much closer to the real answer. It's when the evidence of an experiment supports their theories that the theorists feel a bit let down. Science is about the search for knowledge, not the accumulation of it.
reply: What's amazing is that it's getting bigger. That is the true obstacle to interstellar travel. It's when the evidence of an experiment supports their theories that the theorists feel a bit let down. Science is about the search for knowledge, not the accumulation of it.
title: Just how big is the universe?

content: Einstein's theories will very likely be found to be incomplete and require a tad of "tweaking" here and there, but in the main, they've been borne out by observation and repetition! The catch is in reconciling his thoughts with the discipline of Quantum Physics (or vice-versa)! It is not our belief or disbelief that can make or unmake the fact. ~ Thomas Paine
reply: Einstein's theories will very likely be found to be incomplete and require a tad of "tweaking" here and there, but in the main, they've been borne out by observation and repetition!
